recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions. , Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé, Arabesque balances, Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, Flexibility stretching for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.            , Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. for 10 repetitions on each for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras: Work on your port de bras by practicing flowing arm movements, focusing on making smooth transitions and expressive gestures., Dance to different music: Explore different styles of music and try dancing to each one, focusing on expressing the mood and emotion of the music through your movements., Free movement improvisation: Let your body move freely and spontaneously, without any set choreography. Focus on expressing yourself through movement and exploring different levels and dynamics..

Jazz Contraction is a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.. For practicing Jazz Contraction as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Pilates teaser, Yoga wheel pose, Dance floor work for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Bend knees, lowering into deep plié., Curve spine forward, engaging core., Drop head, maintaining neck alignment., Incorporate dynamic full-body movements. for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.

Jazz Contraction is a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.. For practicing Jazz Contraction as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Pilates roll-up, Yoga boat pose, Seated twists for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Bend knees, lowering into plié., Curve spine forward, contracting core., Drop head, maintaining neck alignment., Add fluid arm movements for style. for 10 repetitions for 20 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.
